content: The Act may be cited as the "Centennial Monetary Commission Act of 2013". The Federal Reserve System was established by Congress in 1913 following the Panic of 1907. It consists of the Board of Governors in Washington, D.C., and 12 Federal Reserve Banks across the U.S., owned by national and state-chartered commercial banks. The Federal Reserve was initially mandated to provide an elastic currency on a fractional reserve basis. Congress later added a financial stability mandate for the Fed to act as a lender of last resort during financial crises. In 1977, Congress changed the Fed's mandate to focus on maximum employment and stable prices, recognizing the importance of price stability to the economy. The recent economic challenges, including the housing bubble burst and financial crisis of 2008, have led to job losses and output decline. Policymakers are reassessing financial institutions to strengthen the system. The Federal Reserve has taken extraordinary measures, such as quantitative easing and keeping interest rates low, to address the economic challenges. In response to recent economic challenges, the Federal Reserve has implemented extraordinary measures like quantitative easing and maintaining low interest rates. Congress is now reevaluating the proper mandate for the Federal Reserve in conducting monetary policy in the 21st century. Establishment of the Centennial Monetary Commission to reevaluate the Federal Reserve's mandate in conducting monetary policy in the 21st century. The Commission will study the impact of US monetary policy since 1913 on the economy, evaluate different operational regimes for achieving economic goals, including discretion, price level targeting, inflation rate targeting, and nominal GDP targeting. The Commission will study the impact of US monetary policy since 1913 on the economy, evaluating different operational regimes for achieving economic goals. Recommendations will be made on nominal GDP targeting, monetary policy rules, the gold standard, legislative mandate, operational regime, securities used in open market operations, and transparency issues. A report containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations will be submitted to Congress by June 30, 2014. The Commission will consist of 6 voting members, including the Chair and Vice Chair of the Joint Economic Committee, members from the Committee on Financial Services of the House of Representatives, and their respective ranking minority members. The Commission will consist of 6 voting members, appointed by various leaders in Congress, including the Chair and Vice Chair of the Joint Economic Committee, members from the Committee on Financial Services of the House of Representatives, and their respective ranking minority members. The Commission, established by leaders in Congress, will have 6 voting members appointed by various officials, with 2 non-voting members appointed by the Secretary of the Treasury and the Chair of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. Members serve for the life of the Commission, appointed between January 5, 2013, and 30 days after the Act's enactment. Vacancies are filled as per original appointment, and meetings are held as needed. Vacancies are filled as per original appointment, and meetings are held as needed. The Commission shall hold initial and further meetings as necessary, with a quorum of seven voting members required. The Commission, subcommittees, or members can hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence. The Commission can contract with government and private agencies. It can also obtain official data from various government entities. The Commission, subcommittees, or members can request information from government agencies as authorized by law. The General Services Administration will provide assistance to the Commission. The General Services Administration will provide administrative support and services to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. Other departments and agencies of the United States can also offer additional support as requested by the Commission. The Commission is allowed to use the United States mails like other government entities. COMMISSION PERSONNEL. The Chair of the Commission has the authority to appoint and determine the pay of staff members. The staff can be appointed without following certain civil service laws and may be paid without restrictions, except for exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission is also allowed to hire consultants for temporary services as needed. The Commission can appoint staff members and determine their pay without following certain civil service laws. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Commission will terminate on February 28, 2015, and may conclude its activities before termination. Appropriations are authorized to carry out the Act until the Commission terminates.
